snippet.textDisplay:
I am quite upset by the misinformation that's in this video. I normally really like kurzgesagt, but if you look at their references for the making of this video they actually used a source that is sponsored by Nestle witch is a heavily dairy company, Probably because they cannot find any peer reviewed studies that support their bias.
It makes me upset because I do really like Kurzgesagt videos but if they are going to be using resources that are so biased then what's the point? Can you even really trust what they even say? Do all kurzgesagt videos have terrible references?
You would think that if they were making informative videos and spent their time researching things they would know how to find studies that are not sponsored by the dairy industry!!
Come on guys you can do better!
snippet.textOriginal:
I am quite upset by the misinformation that's in this video. I normally really like kurzgesagt, but if you look at their references for the making of this video they actually used a source that is sponsored by Nestle witch is a heavily dairy company, Probably because they cannot find any peer reviewed studies that support their bias. 
It makes me upset because I do really like Kurzgesagt videos but if they are going to be using resources that are so biased then what's the point? Can you even really trust what they even say? Do all kurzgesagt videos have terrible references? 
You would think that if they were making informative videos and spent their time researching things they would know how to find studies that are not sponsored by the dairy industry!! 
Come on guys you can do better!

snippet.textDisplay: Two very huge omissions. There are no enzymes left in milk after you Boil them all away in pasteurization. Secondly you said yourself it's for the baby cow. If humans wish to be the size of a cow drink cows milk  pasteurization creares a useless nutrient for the body to dispose of because there are no enzymes left for the body itself to process it. We are not designed as humans to consume it. That is the purpose of breast milk of the mother as an infant. Not a lifelong necessary nutrient. What we need is in nature herself to provide. There is more calcium in Green leafy plants and Almonds than from devoid unuseable breast milk of a cow

snippet.textDisplay: It's not complicated. It's simple. Dairy is not good for the environment, animals or human beings. Today nutritional science can definitively say that not consuming dairy is healthier than consuming it.

snippet.textDisplay: I just think about all the milk I was forced to drink in school. If you weren't allergic you were forced to have it. But I had a very sedentary lifestyle. This lead to primarily drinking milk and I was also pretty chubby.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is a claim about cowsmilk not being harmful to the majority of the population (8:57). However you say that up to 65% of the world population is lactose intolerant. How did you measure this 'majority' then?
Secondly i notice that Kurzgezagt uses the word 'milk' when they mean cowsmilk. Shouldn't we use a more specific language to discuss this theme? The milk can be human-milk (mothermilk), but also from goats and dogs and cats... would be nice to get more specific here. Also: what are the effects on stealing the milk from another mammal? Isn't it more healthy to let a calf drink milk from a cow and a human baby to drink it from the homo sapiens? ;)

In general, good video though. I'd say in the conclusion though that it actually IS harmful to the majority of the population. Both for health as for ecological reasons. I'd choose plant based milk over animal-milk theft. Plus: drink water more often: it's really good ;)
snippet.textOriginal:
There is a claim about cowsmilk not being harmful to the majority of the population (8:57). However you say that up to 65% of the world population is lactose intolerant. How did you measure this 'majority' then?
Secondly i notice that Kurzgezagt uses the word 'milk' when they mean cowsmilk. Shouldn't we use a more specific language to discuss this theme? The milk can be human-milk (mothermilk), but also from goats and dogs and cats... would be nice to get more specific here. Also: what are the effects on stealing the milk from another mammal? Isn't it more healthy to let a calf drink milk from a cow and a human baby to drink it from the homo sapiens? ;) 

In general, good video though. I'd say in the conclusion though that it actually IS harmful to the majority of the population. Both for health as for ecological reasons. I'd choose plant based milk over animal-milk theft. Plus: drink water more often: it's really good ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
My father works as a vet for big animals, mainly cows.
I don't get to farms often but been there with him a few times and I wouldn't say it causes a lot of suffering. But here, in Czech Republic, we actually keep cows mostly outside if possible. Other countries, as I've heard, keep them mostly inside, sometimes their whole life. So that's one of the main problems I would say.
snippet.textOriginal:
My father works as a vet for big animals, mainly cows.
I don't get to farms often but been there with him a few times and I wouldn't say it causes a lot of suffering. But here, in Czech Republic, we actually keep cows mostly outside if possible. Other countries, as I've heard, keep them mostly inside, sometimes their whole life. So that's one of the main problems I would say.

snippet.textDisplay:
Does the 3% of all greenhouse gasses from the dairy industry take into account the plants grown to feed the cows (which may have been "wasted or unused land prior to, with larger plants like corn removing more CO2 from the air than grass)? Does it include data from cows when they are not lactating or all cows all year round? Are heifers included in this percentage as well?
Also what would happen if a very young child were to consume another animal's milk before their GIT were to close off to larger molecules? Would hormones be a concern then or would drinking colostrum be the only real concern?
snippet.textOriginal:
Does the 3% of all greenhouse gasses from the dairy industry take into account the plants grown to feed the cows (which may have been "wasted or unused land prior to, with larger plants like corn removing more CO2 from the air than grass)? Does it include data from cows when they are not lactating or all cows all year round? Are heifers included in this percentage as well? 
Also what would happen if a very young child were to consume another animal's milk before their GIT were to close off to larger molecules? Would hormones be a concern then or would drinking colostrum be the only real concern?

snippet.textDisplay: I can drink a gallon of milk a week by myself. I'm also 6'2", healthy, and built like an ox even at 47 years old. For those of us descended from northern European stock, it's perfectly natural to consume milk throughout our lives because we have a mutation which allows us to do so. It would actually be far more unnatural for me to consume soy milk, because I'm genetically adapted for drinking the real thing.
snippet.textOriginal: I can drink a gallon of milk a week by myself. I'm also 6'2", healthy, and built like an ox even at 47 years old. For those of us descended from northern European stock, it's perfectly natural to consume milk throughout our lives because we have a mutation which allows us to do so. It would actually be far more unnatural for me to consume soy milk, because I'm genetically adapted for drinking the real thing.

My neighbor owns one of the biggest dairy farms in Wisconsin. She and most of her worked have told me that since cows don’t stop producing milk until much later that cows will walk right up to the milk machines and get milked because the abundance irritates them.

If you can find evidence of this I will be very thankful
